name: Garuda
shortDescription: Divine eagle-man, king of birds and mount of Vishnu, sworn enemy of serpents
fullDescription: Garuda (Sanskrit: ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§°, Garu·∏ça) is the king of birds and the vahana (mount) of Lord Vishnu in Hindu and Buddhist mythology. Born from an egg to the sage Kashyapa and Vinata, Garuda emerged fully grown, blazing with the radiance of fire, so bright that the gods mistook him for Agni, the fire god. He is depicted as a magnificent being with the body of a strong man, the golden wings, beak, and talons of an eagle, and a white face with a sharp eagle's beak. Garuda's most famous exploit was stealing amrita (the nectar of immortality) from the gods to free his mother from slavery to his aunt Kadru, mother of the serpents (nagas). Though he successfully retrieved the amrita, Vishnu intercepted him and, impressed by Garuda's power and devotion, made him his eternal mount. Garuda became the sworn enemy of all nagas (serpents), preying upon them and representing the eternal conflict between birds and serpents, good and evil, light and darkness. He symbolizes birth, heaven, divine protection, solar energy, and the soul's journey to liberation. Garuda appears on the royal seal of Thailand and Indonesia, demonstrating his cultural importance across South and Southeast Asia.

properties.name: Physical Form
properties.value: Man with golden eagle wings, beak, and talons

properties.name: Birth
properties.value: Emerged from egg blazing with solar radiance

properties.name: Great Deed
properties.value: Stole amrita from heaven to free his mother

properties.value: Solar power, divine protection, liberation, speed

mythologyContexts.usage: Mount of Vishnu; protector against serpents and evil; symbol of divine power and speed; represents the soul's journey toward liberation; invoked for protection and overcoming obstacles

textReferences.context: Complete story of Garuda's birth and theft of amrita
Garuda's birth and becoming Vishnu's mount
Purana named after and narrated by Garuda to King Tarkshya

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Garuda represents the solar principle‚Äîbirth, radiance, power, and ascent. His golden wings symbolize divine light and spiritual elevation. As Vishnu's mount, he represents the vehicle of divine consciousness, carrying the preserver god across the cosmos. The eagle form connects to sky, wind, and the ability to see with clarity from great heights‚Äîspiritual perspective. His enmity with serpents (nagas) symbolizes the eternal conflict between light and darkness, spirit and matter, heaven and earth. Stealing amrita to free his mother represents liberation through spiritual power and filial devotion. His speed represents swiftness in overcoming obstacles and reaching enlightenment. The man-bird form shows the fusion of human consciousness with divine freedom of flight.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Garuda became one of Hinduism's most important divine figures, appearing in temple architecture throughout South and Southeast Asia. He serves as the national emblem of Indonesia and Thailand, demonstrating his pan-Asian significance. In Thai Buddhism, Garuda (Krut) battles with nagas in temple art. Vishnu temples feature Garuda prominently, with devotees believing Garuda worship protects against snake bites and poison. The Garuda Purana, supposedly narrated by Garuda, is recited during Hindu funeral rites. Garuda's image wards off evil and poison. His story emphasizes loyalty, devotion, and the power to overcome impossible obstacles through determination.

mythologyContexts.usage: One of the eight classes of supernatural beings; protector of dharma; enemy of nagas; symbol of wisdom's ability to overcome ignorance

textReferences.context: Garuda as one of eight classes of beings

mythologyContexts.symbolism: In Buddhism, Garuda represents wisdom overcoming ignorance (symbolized by serpents). His ability to fly represents liberation from the cycle of rebirth. His fierce nature protects Buddhist teachings from corruption.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Garuda appears in Buddhist art across Asia, from Tibetan thangkas to Japanese temple architecture. In Tibetan Buddhism, Garuda (Khyung) is one of the four dignities. In Japanese Buddhism, Karura guards dharma.

archetypes.name: Divine Mount/Companion
examples: Enables divine intervention in mortal realm
archetypes.context: Garuda is the archetypal divine mount‚Äîthe supernatural companion who carries divinity and represents divine attributes (speed, power, protection).

archetypes.name: The Hero's Journey
examples: Overcomes divine obstacles (Indra, fire ring, wheel)
Returns with prize to free mother
archetypes.context: Garuda's theft of amrita follows the hero's journey‚Äîreceiving a call (free mother), facing trials, obtaining treasure, and returning transformed (becoming Vishnu's mount).

archetypes.name: Light vs. Darkness
archetypes.context: Garuda embodies the light archetype in eternal conflict with serpents (darkness), representing the opposition of solar/celestial forces against chthonic/earthly ones.

archetypes.name: The Trickster
examples: Technically fulfills promise while achieving goal
Uses cunning as well as strength
archetypes.context: Garuda displays trickster qualities in his quest‚Äîusing cleverness to steal from heaven, finding loopholes, and turning obstacles into advantages.

firstAttestation.description: Estimated based on mythology literary tradition
